Case 21-770, Document 20-2, 04/01/2021, 3068530, Page121 of 200

1 regular contact with the government, is removed in a property
2 in the United States. That's the opposite of hiding. So we
3 think that those kinds of facts, I'm sure, your Honor, if your
4 Honor decides to keep the proceedings open and give us a chance
5 to come on some issues, I'm sure we will have some more facts
6 tomorrow and the next day, all with the disclaimer, we just
7 learned this, your Honor. They have been investigating this
8 case for ten years, your Honor, okay?
9
10 So let me turn now to another factor that the
11 government made argument about briefly, two more factors under
12 31(g)(3), the history and characteristics of the defendant. We
13 heard several times that there was a -- that detention should
14 be warranted because there is a perjury charge. Very quickly,
15 your Honor, we submit this does not tip the balance in the 3142
16 analysis that the court has to perform.
17 First and foremost, the defendant is, of course,
18 presumed innocent; and, secondly, the allegation and nature of
19 the perjury, if the court has been through the indictment, is
20 someone who denies guilt, who says they are innocent, is asked
21 in a deposition did you do that and says no, the government
22 charges them with perjury. That is not -- other than the fact
23 that it's an indicted charge, they are still entitled to the
24 weight the court would give a not indicted charge. That's all
25 the weight it should be given.

Let me turn to another factor that the government
